newsitem.title: USA: Immunex drug eases rheumatoid arthritis-report.
newsitem.headline: Immunex drug eases rheumatoid arthritis-report.

text.p: Preliminary tests have found that a drug that blocks the effects of a naturally occurring protein in the body can significantly reduce the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, according to a study reported in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine.
The drug is known as TNFR:Fc and is manufactured under the brand name Enbrel by Seattle-based Immunex Corp.

In the preliminary study, a team of doctors at six U.S. medical centres found that the highest dose of Enbrel -- two injections per week -- reduced the number of tender or swollen joints by 61 percent compared with a 25 percent reduction for volunteers who received twice-weekly placebo shots.

The drug is not a cure for rheumatoid arthritis, which typically afflicts the fingers, wrists, feet, ankles, shoulders and hips. Three months after treatment was stopped, the symptoms began to return.

Nonetheless, the research team led by Dr. Larry W. Moreland of the University of Alabama at Birmingham concluded that giving Enbrel "is a valid approach to the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis" -- the most severe type of arthritis, in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the joints and surrounding soft tissues.

In an editorial in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, Drs. Gary Firestein and Nathan Zvaifler of the University of California School of Medicine in La Jolla said, "We must be careful to avoid excessive enthusiasm for the results of short-term studies."
They said the effectiveness of most arthritis treatments tends to wane over time. "Typically, less than 20 percent of patients continue a particular second-line treatment for five years."
Some discontinue treatment because of side effects and others do it because the treatment stops working.

Enbrel is designed to work by blocking the effect of a naturally occurring protein known as tumour necrosis factor (TNF), which influences the immune system. Researchers have known for about a decade that TNF levels rise in the joint fluid of persons with arthritis and in the blood of people who are experiencing joint pain.
Forty-eight men and 132 women were volunteers in the study, which was paid for by Immunex.
